instruction: How does the proposed method, which integrates object-based post-classification refinement (OBPR) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs), compare to traditional methods in terms of classification accuracy for land use and land cover (LULC) mapping using Sentinel optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data?
Output:
The proposed method, which integrates object-based post-classification refinement (OBPR) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs), outperforms traditional methods in terms of classification accuracy for land use and land cover (LULC) mapping using Sentinel optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data. The study compared the proposed method with traditional methods such as object-based image analysis (OBIA) support vector machine (SVM) and random forest (RF). 

The results showed that SVM and RF could benefit more from the combined use of optical and SAR data compared with CNN. However, the spatial information learned by CNN was found to be very effective for classification. By utilizing OBPR, which labels each image object with the most frequent land cover category of its pixels, the proposed method was able to extract spatial features and maintain object boundaries, leading to improved classification accuracy.

The proposed method achieved an overall accuracy (OA) of 95.33% for the Sentinel Guangzhou dataset, OA of 77.64% for the Zhuhai-Macau local climate zones (LCZ) dataset, and OA of 95.70% for the University of Pavia dataset with only 10 labeled samples per class.
